The city is ticketing people parking on proctor again. This is very unfair. Historically, the right side of proctor has been parking spots and only starting earlier this year did they reclassified that side of the street as a sidewalk and started ticketing people. No signs were placed to inform of this change. People who work in the area are aware because they have received tickets or know of people that have received tickets. However, people who are stopping by such as residents who are visiting 1010 for services or going to the food pantry on Wednesdays are not aware of the change and are getting tickets or worse, getting their cars towed. Today, they started to ticket people who were getting food at the food pantry. How can we do this to people who don't have enough people to eat? Either place signs alerting people not to park there or stop ticketing our most vulnerable residents!
address: Intersection Of Massachusetts Ave & Proctor St, Roxbury

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector states the BWSC  is repairing a patch that was deemed not acceptable to City standards . The contractor excavated the patch and placed a base course of asphalt. . In order to have the best final paving product, the city allows the utility company to leave the base course down low for a few days to allow the lift to set up properly in preparation for the final top course. What you observed was the repair in the binder base course phase. The top course is scheduled to be topped in the next few days. The City apologizes for the inconvenience. Any questions or concerns you may contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. The parcel known as Chandler Tremont Plaza, which includes the tot lot, is under the jurisdiction of the City of Boston Public Works Department.  The Animal Rescue League plays no role there, as far as we know.  The "permitting" for the park -- that is, the license agreement -- is with the Ellis Memorial social services nonprofit (http://www.ellismemorial.org/), who run day care and early childhood education services in buildings nearby.  The tot lot serves the Ellis Memorial clientele. The Parks Department plays no role regarding the dog park use at the private property held by the Animal Rescue League's Boston Shelter located at 10 Chandler Street. Please contact the Animal Rescue League at 617-427-9170.  Thank you.

description:
Dear Mayor Walsh, MBTA customers have been standing in the open rain, snow, sleet -and brutal sun for nearly 3 years since the upper busway canopy was removed from the Casey Overpass / Forest Hills Station project. 
It is nothing short of a lack of respect for all the hundreds of thousands of people who have had to endure this neglect these past years. With the project now 1.5 years behind schedule, is there not something that can be done to hasten at least this portion of the this publicly funded project? 
I urge you to stand up for the people, and not the companies who have delayed work and are making millions of additional dollars in this public project. 

We are sick and tired of standing in the open elements on our commute to and from work everyday. 

Sincerely, 

Stephan Jacobs 
Roslindale
617-780-9763

A lot of people use Dighton as a way to cut through Brighton Center, which goes right by Winship Elementary.  They are usually driving pretty fast and are probably trying to avoid traffic at Brighton Center.  This is a huge safety concern because a significant number of students walk to school or are dropped off and use the crosswalk to cross Dighton St.  There is a crossing guard there at 9;15, but several students arrive earlier than that for the morning BOKS exercise program that starts at 8:30.  There is not a crossing guard at this time. Just this morning in the 2 minutes it took me to drop off my son, 14 cars zipped past me--none of them slowed down for the crosswalk.  The best solution would be to install a speed hump or bump halfway up the hill so cars slow down before the crosswalk.  If it saves one child's life, it will be worth it.  Please don't wait to do this until someone is either hurt or killed by someone cutting through the school zone.
